articles.headline: 3 Oil Firms May Alter Gulf Leases
articles.snippet: Executives from Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron and ConocoPhillips indicated that they might be willing to give up sizable taxpayer subsidies.
articles.abstract: Executives from Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron and ConocoPhillips indicated that they might be willing to give up sizable taxpayer subsidies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 21 — Facing angry lawmakers from both political parties, executives from three major oil companies — Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron and ConocoPhillips — indicated on Wednesday that they might be willing to give up sizable taxpayer subsidies for drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.

articles.headline: Rioting in China Over Label on College Diplomas
articles.snippet: China's college students must grapple with petty fraud, substandard instruction and an intensely competitive job market.
articles.abstract: China's college students must grapple with petty fraud, substandard instruction and an intensely competitive job market.
articles.lead_paragraph: XINZHENG, China, June 21 — Shengda College in central China has a diverse curriculum, foreign faculty members to teach English and a manicured campus, where weeping willows shade a recreational lake.

articles.headline: Let a Hurricane Huff and Puff
articles.snippet: After two years of horrendous hurricanes, coastal builders are finding eager buyers for their fortified houses.
articles.abstract: After two years of horrendous hurricanes, coastal builders are finding eager buyers for their fortified houses.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the Gulf Coast of Texas, Jim Hayes is building houses on concrete stilts that he says will shrug off winds of more than 130 miles an hour and will easily survive the worst hurricane flooding. Near Orlando, Fla., modest but striking cottages are being built with safe rooms and ballistic nylon storm shutters. In the Florida Panhandle, Jason Comer is putting up a village of gleaming white mansions with eight-inch concrete walls and heavy, ridged concrete roofs.

articles.headline: FedEx Profit Helps Propel Stock Market
articles.snippet: With Wednesday's broad rally, the market recovered much of the ground it had lost in the last two weeks.
articles.abstract: With Wednesday's broad rally, the market recovered much of the ground it had lost in the last two weeks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Strong earnings and an upbeat forecast from a corporate bellwether sent the stock market up broadly yesterday, helping it recover much of the ground lost in the last two weeks.

articles.headline: U.S. Agent Dies in Shootout With Prison Guard
articles.snippet: The guard was one of six accused of giving contraband to female inmates in Florida in exchange for sex and money.
articles.abstract: The guard was one of six accused of giving contraband to female inmates in Florida in exchange for sex and money.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 21 — A federal agent was killed and a prison officer wounded Wednesday in a shootout with a guard at a federal prison here. The guard, who was about to be arrested in connection with a sex ring, also died in the gun battle.

articles.abstract: Analysts predict that the drugs will become blockbusters, with more than $1 billion in worldwide sales each.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as diabetes rates reach epidemic levels worldwide, four new drugs are generating optimism among doctors as well as Wall Street analysts.

articles.headline: FedEx Profit Helps Propel Stock Market
articles.snippet: Strong earnings and an upbeat forecast from a corporate bellwether sent the stock market up broadly yesterday, helping it recover much of the ground lost in the last two weeks.     Investors turned their attention from fears of inflation, an econo...
articles.abstract: Strong earnings and an upbeat forecast from a corporate bellwether sent the stock market up broadly yesterday, helping it recover much of the ground lost in the last two weeks.     Investors turned their attention from fears of inflation, an economic slowdown and higher interest rates to numbers that remain far more positive: profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Strong earnings and an upbeat forecast from a corporate bellwether sent the stock market up broadly yesterday, helping it recover much of the ground lost in the last two weeks.

articles.headline: A Coffee Connoisseur on a Mission: Buy High and Sell High
articles.snippet: Geoff Watts turned up recently at the ceremony capping Nicaragua's 2006 Cup of Excellence coffee competition in the steamy 500-year-old Convent of San Francisco here. Mr. Watts, 32, is the green coffee buyer for Intelligentsia Coffee, a fast-growi...
articles.abstract: Geoff Watts turned up recently at the ceremony capping Nicaragua's 2006 Cup of Excellence coffee competition in the steamy 500-year-old Convent of San Francisco here. Mr. Watts, 32, is the green coffee buyer for Intelligentsia Coffee, a fast-growing privately owned retail and wholesale company in Chicago.     Coffee, Mr. Watts says, is his life, and he tries to attend most of the competitions in Latin America each year to find the best beans and build lasting relationships with growers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRANADA, Nicaragua - Geoff Watts turned up recently at the ceremony capping Nicaragua's 2006 Cup of Excellence coffee competition in the steamy 500-year-old Convent of San Francisco here. Mr. Watts, 32, is the green coffee buyer for Intelligentsia Coffee, a fast-growing privately owned retail and wholesale company in Chicago.

articles.abstract: WELCOME to high-definition-DVD-FAQs.com, your one-stop info resource about the next generation of home movie equipment! Here you'll find all the frequently asked questions about the new DVD players  and, better yet, the answers.     Forrester Research says that 17 percent of American households have high-def TV screens; no wonder the electronics industry thinks that DVD technology is ready for an upgrade, too. After all, the 60,000 movies already available on DVD may look good on your TV today -- but they're not true high definition. You're not seeing the full color, clarity and contrast your high-def screen is capable of.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELCOME to high-definition-DVD-FAQs.com, your one-stop info resource about the next generation of home movie equipment! Here you'll find all the frequently asked questions about the new DVD players and, better yet, the answers.

articles.headline: Hussein Lawyer Seized and Slain in Baghdad Raid
articles.snippet: Saddam Hussein's trial on crimes against humanity was struck by new violence on Wednesday when a senior lawyer on his defense team was abducted, beaten and shot to death. The defense lawyer was the third to be killed since the trial began in Octob...
articles.abstract: Saddam Hussein's trial on crimes against humanity was struck by new violence on Wednesday when a senior lawyer on his defense team was abducted, beaten and shot to death. The defense lawyer was the third to be killed since the trial began in October, and the 10th person associated with the court trying Mr. Hussein to be killed in the last 18 months.     According to his widow, the lawyer, Khamis al-Obeidi, 39, was asleep when at least 10 gunmen in civilian clothes stormed their home in the mostly Sunni Arab district of Slaikh at 7 a.m. and pulled him from bed within view of his three school-age children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: 4 Diabetes Drugs Are Seen Raising Hope and Profit
articles.snippet: Even as diabetes rates reach epidemic levels worldwide, four new drugs are generating optimism among doctors as well as Wall Street analysts.      New drugs alone will not reverse rising rates of Type 2 diabetes, a condition that affects about 20 ...
articles.abstract: Even as diabetes rates reach epidemic levels worldwide, four new drugs are generating optimism among doctors as well as Wall Street analysts.      New drugs alone will not reverse rising rates of Type 2 diabetes, a condition that affects about 20 million Americans and is closely tied to obesity and lack of physical activity. And doctors caution that for the foreseeable future, diabetes will remain a progressively worsening disease that can cause devastating complications.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as diabetes rates reach epidemic levels worldwide, four new drugs are generating optimism among doctors as well as Wall Street analysts.

articles.headline: U.S. Agent Dies in Shootout With Prison Guard
articles.snippet: A federal agent was killed and a prison officer wounded Wednesday in a shootout with a guard at a federal prison here. The guard, who was about to be arrested in connection with a sex ring, also died in the gun battle.      The guard, Ralph Hill, ...
articles.abstract: A federal agent was killed and a prison officer wounded Wednesday in a shootout with a guard at a federal prison here. The guard, who was about to be arrested in connection with a sex ring, also died in the gun battle.      The guard, Ralph Hill, was one of six who were indicted Tuesday, accused of giving contraband to female inmates at the Federal Correctional Institution in exchange for sex and money. The low-security prison houses about 1,400 women on the eastern edge of Tallahassee.
articles.lead_paragraph: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 21 - A federal agent was killed and a prison officer wounded Wednesday in a shootout with a guard at a federal prison here. The guard, who was about to be arrested in connection with a sex ring, also died in the gun battle.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Decides to Embrace War as Issue
articles.snippet: Just a few weeks ago, some Republicans were openly fretting about the war in Iraq and its effect on their re-election prospects, with particularly vulnerable lawmakers worried that its growing unpopularity was becoming a drag on their campaigns.  ...
articles.abstract: Just a few weeks ago, some Republicans were openly fretting about the war in Iraq and its effect on their re-election prospects, with particularly vulnerable lawmakers worried that its growing unpopularity was becoming a drag on their campaigns.     But there was little sign of such nervousness on Wednesday as Republican after Republican took to the Senate floor to offer an unambiguous embrace of the Iraq war and to portray Democrats as advocates of an overly hasty withdrawal that would have grave consequences for the security of the United States. Like their counterparts in the House last week, they accused Democrats of espousing ''retreat and defeatism.''
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 21 - Just a few weeks ago, some Republicans were openly fretting about the war in Iraq and its effect on their re-election prospects, with particularly vulnerable lawmakers worried that its growing unpopularity was becoming a drag on their campaigns.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: Video of Ill-Fated Uzbek Rising Offers Haunting, Complex View
articles.snippet: The young man with an assault rifle, a convicted killer, stood beneath a statue in the central square of the Uzbek city of Andijon. He had been freed from prison in an armed raid the night before.     It was May 13, 2005. The man, Daniyor Akbarov,...
articles.abstract: The young man with an assault rifle, a convicted killer, stood beneath a statue in the central square of the Uzbek city of Andijon. He had been freed from prison in an armed raid the night before.     It was May 13, 2005. The man, Daniyor Akbarov, addressed a growing crowd of unarmed civilians, telling them he was part of a group of 100 to 150 armed men that had already lost 20 or 30 members in a night of fighting. He said that they were trying to change Uzbekistan, one of the world's most repressive nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, June 16 - The young man with an assault rifle, a convicted killer, stood beneath a statue in the central square of the Uzbek city of Andijon. He had been freed from prison in an armed raid the night before.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers and Ethan Wilensky-Lanford

articles.headline: 3 Oil Firms May Alter Gulf Leases
articles.snippet: Facing angry lawmakers from both political parties, executives from three major oil companies -- Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron and ConocoPhillips -- indicated on Wednesday that they might be willing to give up sizable taxpayer subsidies for drilling ...
articles.abstract: Facing angry lawmakers from both political parties, executives from three major oil companies -- Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron and ConocoPhillips -- indicated on Wednesday that they might be willing to give up sizable taxpayer subsidies for drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.     But one of the most active players in the gulf, the Kerr-McGee Corporation, showed no signs of compromise and told a House hearing that it was entitled to the subsidies -- known as royalty relief -- even if oil prices remained above $70 a barrel. And Exxon Mobil said it saw no reason for the subsidies to be changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, June 21 - Facing angry lawmakers from both political parties, executives from three major oil companies -- Royal Dutch Shell, Chevron and ConocoPhillips -- indicated on Wednesday that they might be willing to give up sizable taxpayer subsidies for drilling in the Gulf of Mexico.

articles.headline: An Advisor Who Works Behind the Scenes Aids Paper Heirs
articles.snippet: In the melee that erupted last week between the Chandler family and the Tribune Company, it has been hard to tell who is driving the Chandler caravan. After all, the Chandlers, who owned The Los Angeles Times for more than a century, are a diffuse...
articles.abstract: In the melee that erupted last week between the Chandler family and the Tribune Company, it has been hard to tell who is driving the Chandler caravan. After all, the Chandlers, who owned The Los Angeles Times for more than a century, are a diffuse clan numbering some 170 members, many of whom have never met one another.      One of the major players behind the scenes is Thomas Unterman. He is neither a member of the family nor a trustee overseeing its billions, nor is he one of the trust's appointees on the Tribune board. Rather, Mr. Unterman is a lawyer turned media executive turned venture capitalist who has worked for the family for years. He has acquired a reputation as a financial and legal wizard for helping put together a series of complex and sometimes contentious deals the family and the former Times Mirror company did in the 1990's.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the melee that erupted last week between the Chandler family and the Tribune Company, it has been hard to tell who is driving the Chandler caravan. After all, the Chandlers, who owned The Los Angeles Times for more than a century, are a diffuse clan numbering some 170 members, many of whom have never met one another.

articles.snippet: Military prosecutors charged eight American servicemen with murder and other crimes in the death of an Iraqi civilian. Page A13.

articles.headline: Let a Hurricane Huff and Puff
articles.snippet: On the Gulf Coast of Texas, Jim Hayes is building houses on concrete stilts that he says will shrug off winds of more than 130 miles an hour and will easily survive the worst hurricane flooding. Near Orlando, Fla., modest but striking cottages are...
articles.abstract: On the Gulf Coast of Texas, Jim Hayes is building houses on concrete stilts that he says will shrug off winds of more than 130 miles an hour and will easily survive the worst hurricane flooding. Near Orlando, Fla., modest but striking cottages are being built with safe rooms and ballistic nylon storm shutters. In the Florida Panhandle, Jason Comer is putting up a village of gleaming white mansions with eight-inch concrete walls and heavy, ridged concrete roofs.      After two years of horrendous hurricanes, with more catastrophic weather expected, a few dozen developers and contractors along the Southern coasts, from Texas to the Carolinas, have begun to produce a new generation of houses designed to withstand just about anything that nature can throw at them.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the Gulf Coast of Texas, Jim Hayes is building houses on concrete stilts that he says will shrug off winds of more than 130 miles an hour and will easily survive the worst hurricane flooding. Near Orlando, Fla., modest but striking cottages are being built with safe rooms and ballistic nylon storm shutters. In the Florida Panhandle, Jason Comer is putting up a village of gleaming white mansions with eight-inch concrete walls and heavy, ridged concrete roofs.
